description:
Ehrlichia canis str. Jake is a bacterial pathogen that belongs to the genus Ehrlichia, which is a member of the family Anaplasmataceae. It is an obligate intracellular bacterium that primarily infects and replicates within the cytoplasm of monocytes and macrophages in its mammalian hosts.

Ehrlichia canis str. Jake is the causative agent of canine monocytic ehrlichiosis, a tick-borne disease that primarily affects domestic dogs. The bacterium is transmitted by the brown dog tick, Rhipicephalus sanguineus, and can cause a range of clinical symptoms in infected dogs, including fever, lethargy, anorexia, weight loss, thrombocytopenia, and potentially severe hemorrhagic disorders.

The strain "Jake" is a well-characterized isolate of Ehrlichia canis that has been used extensively in research to study the pathogenesis, host immune responses, and potential treatment strategies for canine monocytic ehrlichiosis. This strain has contributed to our understanding of the molecular mechanisms and virulence factors involved in the infection and evasion of the host's immune system by Ehrlichia canis.
